Group Collabs.

SelfMade | Aug 2019

Start, browse, and join a group collaboration with like-minded e-commerce brands.

Background

SelfMade launched SelfMade Collabs, a free collaboration platform for e-commerce owners early summer 2019. If you own an online business, you can browse, favorite, and request a “collab” such as an Instagram giveaway with other e-commerce brands.

After 3 months, we reached 2000 profile created. However, active users—those who have taken such actions as favorite another brand or request a collab within the past 30 days—only account for roughly ⅓ of total users. Our goal is to bring this number up.

Problem & Research

For the past few months, we have been conducting weekly user interviews with e-commerce business owners; some were Collab users, some were our managed partners. We also studied event funnels and watched users’ sessions on Collabs using FullStory.

Based on frequent communication with our users, we had a couple of theories on why users didn’t remain active on Collabs:

  • Users did not fully understand the idea of a “collab” and were nervous about clicking the “Request a Collab” button. Is it going to send the other brand a n invite or message? What does a collab look like? How does this benefit my business? Information about Collabs and how it works was scant since it was a new platform.
  • Users who sent out collab requests were discouraged by others’ unresponsiveness. Because they could only send out 1on1 requests, they felt as if they were shooting the dark. The 1on1 method, which was supposed to give “shy” users ample room to explore, was starting to be proven inefficient and ineffective.
  • Users find that setting up a collab is a demanding process. They want an easier entry point which also allows more collaborators to join and broaden the collab’s audience reach.
  • Users wanted explore other collab options besides Instagram Giveaway, which is a type of collab that we funneled users straight into when they signed up.

Hypothesis

By inverting the 1on1 collab experience so that users can browse ongoing collabs in addition to brands, users will be able to see how a collab works first without having to commit to one. This will optimize the platform for different user personas, allowing host-type users to take the lead and passive users to explore more content.

Product Considerations

Now that we had a rough idea of what we wanted to build, we needed to think about experience holistically, from possible entry points to user roles:

Scope

Keeping in mind the above product considerations, I worked with my PM and the VP of Product to scope out V1 of this feature:

As a HOST, I should be able to:

  • Start a new collab
  • Post the collab
  • Review joining requests (Approve/Deny)
  • Invite brands to the collab

As a PARTICIPANT, I should be able to:

  • Browse for a collab
  • See who has joined (been approved), requested to join, and been invited to join
  • Request to join
  • Message host

As a SelfMade, I should be able to:

  • Organize and post weekly themed collabs based on industry and reach
  • Recommend weekly themed collabs to brands invited to join

Design

Userflow

While scoping out this feature, I mapped out a host and a participant user flow to show the team

Group Collab Card Design

I went through a few iterations of the Group Collab card design. Starting out, I want the cards to be long with clear “Request to join” CTA so that they could carry plenty of information. I also wanted them to look distinct from the brand cards. However, after studying how our users interact with the current brand cards and going through these designs with the team, we decided that the cards should be more visually interesting than wordy, since most uses will click on them and go to the collab detail page anyways.

Host a Collab

When designing this flow, I speculate that hosts won’t receive a lot of requests to join to start with. I decided to make the participant qualification step optional for starters so that more users are inclined to join. I also speculate that this will allow for more cross-industry collabs.

Join a Collab

Users can request to join from the collab’s detail page. After the host has accepted the request, they can start their collab experience. In the demo below, it’s an Instagram Giveaway collab.

Takeaway

Group Collabs was the product that made me think holistically about different states of a user flow more than any features I’ve designed. It made me think about things that don’t happen on the immediate product UI such as email notifications and email entry points, things that get triggered by an action such as counters, labels, and their various states. Most importantly, it made me realize the value of workflow gamification in encouraging users to complete tasks.
